Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Capital, Coping, and the Displaced: Health, Well-Being, and Resiliency Among Hurricane Harvey Evacuees

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the role of social ties/resources in helping citizens recover from Hurricane Harvey. Social ties/resources in neighborhoods, at work, through religious organizations and through other social groups are vital for helping individuals and families navigate their daily lives. But when disaster strikes, these resources can be disrupted. Given the magnitude and duration of Hurricane Harvey, many citizens in the Houston area have experienced severe disruption to these social resources, but some have been more affected than others. This research will study how social resources are used by people affected by Harvey, and whether they can create new social resources to assist in recovering from the disaster when old ties are broken. It will also help to determine whose social resources have been most adversely affected. For example, is the loss of social resources more acute for lower compared with upper income people, or for racial minorities compared to non-minorities? The research will also determine whether social resources in neighborhoods, for example, have suffered more damage than those involving groups that cross geographic places, such as churches and work groups. The project will investigate several aspects of citizen well-being, including nature and extent of social ties/resources, anxiety, depression, adaptation and resiliency.

This project will develop a sampling frame that covers several of the hardest-hit counties in the Houston and Corpus Christi areas, and will survey 300 people using in-depth, 40 minute interviews. It will sample people who relocated easily as well as those who had more difficulty. In addition, approximately half of the sample will come from citizens located in shelters, churches, and other service provider locations, and the other approximate half from citizens who relocated to non-shelter locations including doubling up with friends and relatives. This sampling strategy will result in considerable variation in strength of social ties, depth of social resources, as well as differences in social background characteristics. The survey instrument is well developed and relies on several measures with proven records of producing reliable results. In addition, the 300 interviews will form a data base that the project will analyze quantitatively, thus enabling use of well-established statistical tools to evaluate key hypotheses. The project is an excellent candidate for RAPID funding because social ties and social resources began to unravel even before the storm hit since some could easily evacuate to safety as others remained because of a wide array of physical, social, and economic burdens. Now, in the aftermath, social resources continue to be fluid, with some strengthening and others deteriorating. The study will provide a baseline for evaluating dynamic changes in these resources, and address key questions in social science regarding the patterns of how social ties/resources develop and decay in the midst of natural disaster. Finally, gathering indicators of well-being, along with assessing their impact provides valuable information to organizations directly and indirectly engaged in disaster preparedness and response. It should not only help us better understand how the victims of Harvey are currently coping, but provide information as to how we as a society are addressing the needs of these victims, thus demonstrating the breadth and wealth of America's social ties/resources, as well its major deficiencies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The preliminary work on this project concluded that Texas Gulf Coast communities possessed both threats and capacities to build community resilience before, during, and after Hurricane Harvey. Before Hurricane Harvey made landfall, Texas Gulf Coast communities’ primary strengths to foster resilience included robust civic participation in community organizations as well as a majority of residents reporting high levels of community engagement. However, a perceived lack of communication about community disaster management plans, low hurricane risk perception, and perceived lack of trust within the African American and Latinx communities threatened many of the coastal communities’ disaster preparedness efforts. 

In the immediate days and weeks following Hurricane Harvey, survivors reported harnessing social support within their close personal networks to get help; however, residents who lacked social capital struggled to get both instrumental and expressive social support. At the outset, the proposed project was interested in examining the role that displacement path(s) played in not only determining social support and social capital, but health and well-being outcomes among survivors as well. Significant differences were found between white and nonwhite residents and the displacement paths that were chosen. Non-white residents were more likely to use traditional shelter options whereas white residents turned to family and friends outside of the disaster-impacted area, which suggests that white residents may have had more social connections or resources that spanned beyond the place they lived. Moreover, our analysis found that residents were generally dissatisfied with displacement options with those persons staying in shelters expressing the highest levels of dissatisfaction, and those staying in hotels/motels reporting the most satisfaction. Over time, residents were seeking and utilizing assistance from the state and federal governments but expressed high degrees of dissatisfaction with the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 

In the months following Hurricane Harvey, social support was still present in communities and people were able to identify hurricane risk factors and preparedness actions that they could and would take in advance of future hurricanes. Individuals with higher levels of perceived social support were less likely to qualify for a probable PTSD diagnosis. Nevertheless, residents also experienced challenging mental health reactions. Slightly over one-quarter of the people that were interviewed, reported enough stress to qualify for a probable PTSD diagnosis. In particular, those residents who were food insecure or had trouble accessing clothing, a place to stay and sleep, or get clean were significantly more likely to qualify for probable PTSD. Additionally, Latinx residents and the displaced were more likely to qualify for a probable PTSD diagnosis than non-Latinx residents and those who did not need to evacuate from their homes or apartments. In terms of risk assessment and preparedness for future hurricanes, displacement paths were associated with climate risk perception. Residents who evacuated during Hurricane Harvey were significantly more likely to view climate change as a personal risk when compared to individuals who stayed in their homes during the hurricane. 

Our collection of preliminary findings illustrate that communities may exhibit several capacities to build resilience, but more work is needed to (a) improve disaster communication and social capital in a way that fosters collaborative relationships between the public and local government, (b) tailor the high level of civic participation to disaster preparedness efforts, and (c) address social and economic constraints associated with challenging mental health reactions. 

Finally, the results of our work continue to underscore the significant racial and economic disparities in disaster resilience, preparedness, and recovery. Communities/neighborhoods all along the Texas Gulf Coast that were occupied by a majority of lower-income and minority populations were slower to recover, faced greater hazards as a result of extreme flooding, and were left with fewer options in their recovery because of both limited personal and community resources. Coastal cities and towns must continue to address these impending social and political crises while rectifying the environmental impact on high-risk populations.
